## Description {#details}

This class implements a glob pattern matcher similar to the one found in bash, but with some key differences.

Namely, that <code>&quot;&#42;&quot;</code> matches all characters and does not exclude path separators.


<ul>
<li><code>&quot;?&quot;</code> matches a single character.</li>
<li><code>&quot;&#42;&quot;</code> matches zero or more characters.</li>
<li><code>&quot;&#91;&lt;chars&gt;&#93;&quot;</code> matches one character in the bracket. Character ranges, e.g., <code>&quot;&#91;a-z&#93;&quot;</code>, and negative sets via <code>&quot;&#91;^ab&#93;&quot;</code> or <code>&quot;&#91;!ab&#93;&quot;</code> are also supported.</li>
<li><code>&quot;&#123;&lt;glob&gt;,...&#125;&quot;</code> matches one of the globs in the list. Nested brace expansions are not supported. If <code>MaxSubPatterns</code> is empty then brace expansions are not supported and characters <code>&quot;&#123;,&#125;&quot;</code> are treated as literals.</li>
<li><code>&quot;\\\\&quot; (a single backslash) escapes the next character so it is treated
  as a literal.

Some known edge cases are:
&#42; \\p &quot;</code>&#93;&quot; is allowed as the first character in a character class, i.e.,
  \\p &quot;&#91;&#93;&#93;&quot; is valid and matches the literal \\p &quot;&#93;&quot;.
&#42; The empty character class, i.e., \\p &quot;&#91;&#93;&quot;, is invalid.
&#42; Empty or singleton brace expansions, e.g., \\p &quot;&#123;&#125;&quot;, \\p &quot;&#123;a&#125;&quot;, are invalid.
&#42; \\p &quot;&#125;&quot; and \\p &quot;,&quot; that are not inside a brace expansion are taken as
  literals, e.g., \\p &quot;,&#125;&quot; is valid but \\p &quot;&#123;&quot; is not.

For example, \\p &quot;&#42;&#91;/\\\\&#93;foo.&#123;c,cpp&#125;&quot; (with two backslashes) will match
(unix or windows) paths to all files named \\p &quot;foo.c&quot; or \\p &quot;foo.cpp&quot;.</li>
</ul>

Definition at line 50 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/globpattern-h">GlobPattern.h</a>.
